instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the retrieval methods for monitoring crop traits?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the retrieval methods for monitoring crop traits using hyperspectral cameras onboard UAVs was the normalized root mean square error (NRMSE). This metric measures the accuracy of the retrieval methods by calculating the difference between the predicted values and the actual values of the crop traits, and then normalizing it by the range of the actual values. 

The NRMSE can provide a quantitative measure of the performance of the retrieval methods in terms of their ability to accurately estimate the leaf area index (LAI), fractional vegetation cover (fCover), and canopy chlorophyll content (CCC) of potato plants.

instruction: What was the effect of illumination variation throughout the crop growing season on the retrieval performance in the study comparing retrieval methods for monitoring crop traits using hyperspectral cameras onboard UAVs?
Output: The study aimed to investigate how the accuracy of variable estimates using different retrieval methods is affected by operating a UAV under variable illumination conditions (cloudy and partially cloudy weather) throughout the growth cycle of a potato crop.

instruction: Can the RFexp method, which yielded the highest accuracies for LAI, fCover, and CCC in the related study, be considered as a superior spectral retrieval method for monitoring crop traits using hyperspectral cameras onboard UAVs compared to traditional methods?
Output: Yes, based on the results of the related study, the RFexp method can be considered as a superior spectral retrieval method for monitoring crop traits using hyperspectral cameras onboard UAVs compared to traditional methods. The RFexp method yielded the highest accuracies for retrieving the leaf area index (LAI), fractional vegetation cover (fCover), and canopy chlorophyll content (CCC) compared to other methods such as the standard look-up table method (LUTstd), improved LUT method (LUTreg), and hybrid methods. The RFexp method was able to reduce the effects of illumination variability and cloud shadows, resulting in higher accuracies. Therefore, the machine learning approach, specifically RFexp, shows promise for the application of UAV-based hyperspectral data in monitoring crop traits.
